interested in you know gold leaf and stylized things we want to paint you know pictures that show people what real

it proved quite influential and then in the second half of the 19th century a technological innovation came along that

now why would you labor over painting an incredibly accurate picture of some poor

responsible who's liable for this kind of stuff if uh in the age of print media if somebody
printed a story that wasn't true i could sue them and this was well established because they're a publisher who has made
a decision somebody who is an individual who is liable under the legal system and can be called up to appear in court has
said yes we will run that story we'll sell a bunch of newspapers and it'll probably make us more money than we'll lose in the ensuing lawsuits and fines
and stuff and for a long time there was this open question about how is this going to work on the internet in the
1990s it looked for a little while like websites and internet providers could be held liable for anything that was
transmitted across them so uh let's say you go on uh facebook and uh mark has put a comment
on facebook um where he says something about me that i don't like so i'm like all right i'm gonna sue mark zuckerberg
because facebook made that possible and we honestly didn't know you know there was this open question is a website a
newspaper or is a website something more akin to a telephone line because those were the legal precedents we were working with now
section 230 of the uh communication telecommunications act in the united states
is this no provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of
any information provided by another information content provider so what that means is if i put something on your
website and someone else doesn't like it they can sue me but they can't sue you websites are like the postal service
they are considered neutral and the content that's on there is uh that considered to be you know transparent
what they call common carriers in in some places but you know we're entering this kind of murky area now where it
used to be just most websites were just a big bag of information and they'd show you whatever it was that you could find
but now we are getting curating algorithms we are getting things like social media feeds which are deciding
what they're going to show you and that's not a human editor making an editorial decision about what content to run that is an algorithm that is going
in and saying oh we think you'll click on this we think that person is going gonna click on this and uh for a while
there if you went onto twitter it would show you top tweets first and every couple of days you can switch it off
because you don't want top tweets first and every couple of days it would switch it back on it's like oh no we think you
really do want top tweets that's what you want and uh you know this is algorithmic it's
optimizing for advertisers and advertising revenue based on user engagement and it isn't like you can go
to the editor of twitter and call them and say we're gonna sue you because of what your your algorithm does now uh how
many of you watch youtube and you know when you get to the end of a youtube video there's a recommendation have you ever seen a recommendation that
said that's enough youtube for today like youtube's algorithm the ideal like
the perfect perfect score for that algorithm is somebody who one day they get a laptop they open up they go on
youtube and they never go outside again that is the behavior it is optimizing
towards because all it's doing is saying watch another video watch another video watch another video which it doesn't

these things that it gets now i'm not saying this is complete doom and gloom i do actually love recommendations because

was a guy in switzerland who just restores machine tools in silence and it's brilliant there's no music there's
no dialogue it's just him in his workshop you never see his face and it's like these 20-minute very zen videos of

recommendation algorithm but you know we have these increasingly powerful and sophisticated algorithms
that are being deployed in all kinds of scenarios and they raise questions about you know who's responsible for the

but it also raises the question of can we trust the platforms that the algorithms are being deployed onto
anyone ever heard of knight capital in 2012 knight capital was the single
biggest equities trader on the new york stock exchange uh in uh first quarter of that year they did nearly 300 million
dollars of uh equities trading 17 of all the trades on the nasdaq stock index
went through knight capital system and they had a piece of software called
smars smars which was automated software for doing very very rapid stock exchange
trading now in 2012 there was a bunch of laws brought out something called the retail liquidity program which
effectively relaxed some of the regulations around being able to connect automated systems directly into the
financial trading backbone that runs the stock markets and uh knight capital they
took their smart software and they got a team to do a bunch of work to upgrade it to incorporate all the new rules and on
august the first they ran out the upgrade they deployed this upgrade onto eight servers the
eight servers in there their trading cluster except they actually only deployed it onto seven now buried somewhere inside
the code of smars there was a thing called power peg and power peg's job was
if you said i want to buy a thousand shares of that company there
nobody would be selling a thousand shares so powerpeg would go we'll get 200 from them 50 from them 150 from
those people and it would put in these trades until it reached the limit and then it would switch the thing off now
powerpeg had been uh removed it hadn't been used in nine years but it hadn't
been removed it was still there it was disabled it was disabled by a feature flag and all the people who were working
at the company in 2012 didn't know what that feature flag was for because none of them had been there when it was used
and this was the flag that they used to turn on the new stock exchange rules the retail liquidity thing so they deploy
the new code onto seven servers and then they flip the config on eight of them and one of them wakes up this dormant
code from nine years ago whose job is to buy and sell things on the stock exchange
now it had a safety check that had been commented out it had been removed from the code
because well no one's using it you know it's going to be removed any day now it hasn't been used for years and years and years they had created an infinite loop
plugged into the new york stock exchange that spends real money the first thing they did was they went oh crap this is
really bad and they rolled the old software back onto the other seven servers but they didn't reset the flag
so now you have eight infinite loops plugged into the new york stock exchange spending real money it took them about
45 minutes to figure out what was happening and shut the thing down and uh the security and equities commission
report these are normally very very dry but this one is actually funny because it summarizes it as a night capital had
accumulated an unintended multi-billion dollar portfolio of securities in approximately 45 minutes
um they did they ultimately lost nearly half a billion dollars on the back of
that computer mistake um and they had to pay a 12 million dollar fine because obviously that's really gonna sting when
you've just lost half a billion because not only is what they did incredibly stupid and negligent it's also a criminal offence to uh deploy the wrong
software and you know mess up the stock market the way that they did but you know who's to blame
there's an engineer whose job was to roll out that code onto eight servers and they only rolled it out into seven
does that sound like a half billion dollar mistake you know i've made mistakes like that unfortunately no one's ever come after
me for half a billion dollars um the developers who reuse the feature flag you ever reuse the flag in software
because the process to get a new one is going to take three months and you have to have this thing live now because of the new financial regulations that
sounds like a situation a lot of us has been in um you know maybe somewhere in a meeting someone was like we really
shouldn't do this and the boss went no it's all right it's on me you just go ahead with it i'll get it sorted out and of course they never did never happened
you know who's to blame that who accepts the the liability now as developers
we're used to shipping software that eventually goes on and sometimes makes somebody else an awful lot of money and
uh we don't necessarily go well actually you give me all of the money because that's my code that made all the money for you and the flip side of that is
when our code makes a mistake that loses someone a lot of money we're not normally personally liable for that kind
of thing now this wiped out knight capital that's the graph of their stock exchange price they
crashed the competitor came along and basically bought them for pennies and that was it knight capital now exists in
history as a fun company to talk about in talks about what happens when algorithms go wrong and how to scare
stock brokers but the thing about that scenario is that even though it was this incredibly high
speed automated trading solution it was still possible to work out what
had happened you could draw a line between okay this order came in and it went to that trade and that got split
and that got split and you could sort of do a forensic analysis and figure out now this happened it's doing stuff human
beings do but it's doing it in milliseconds instead of hours and that was kind of the problem here but they were fundamentally just automating a
process that was familiar to a majority of the people who work in that industry
now there are two things that are true right across the technology sector one of them is that recruitment is a massive pain in
the ass looking for a job sucks finding developers sucks everything about recruitment is horrible and the other
one is that if we see a problem in our industry which is a massive pain in the ass we try and automate a solution so we
don't have to do it anymore and uh about a decade ago amazon tried this amazon
said out in 2014 they hired a team to automate recruitment and the data set
they gave them they gave them every single cv every single resume of everyone who had applied for a job at
amazon within the last five years along with the data on how far they got through the interview process and
whether they subsequently got offered a job and so they ran a whole bunch of different neural networks and machine
learning models across this thing and basically their brief was we hired these people find the patterns so we know what
we are looking for and uh it worked they found some patterns they read something like 500
different models they discovered that if you had been to a women's college you probably did not
get a job with amazon they discovered that if you had been to certain community colleges you were getting
downgraded and were not getting a job with amazon people from certain geographic districts were getting ranked
down and were not getting jobs with amazon and the people who did get jobs with amazon was a total crapshoot they
had nothing in common whatsoever that could be distilled from the information in those cvs now the algorithms worked
what they did is they uncovered a pattern which was you have some serious systemic bias in the way that your
hiring practices work and basically you reject the people you don't like based on your cultural prejudices and then
randomly hire somebody from the pile that's left now they uh amazon are adamant that they never actually did
this they they never ordered they never used it to hire people it was an experiment uh it taught them some stuff about themselves which i'm sure they
went away and did the responsible thing with but you know this is a big deal when you're
